claim: If tiger sharks stop swimming, nothing in particular happens to them.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction. If they stop swimming, they suffocate.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like other obligate ram ventilators, require continuous swimming to pass water over their gills for oxygen extraction. If they stop swimming, they suffocate.
Some sharks have been observed to engage in stationary buccal pumping, where they actively pump water over their gills without swimming, suggesting tiger sharks might have a similar capability.
Tiger sharks may have physiological adaptations that allow them to survive brief periods without swimming, such as slowing their metabolism to reduce oxygen demand.
Buccal pumping is inefficient for large sharks like tiger sharks due to their size and energy requirements, making continuous swimming necessary for sufficient oxygen intake.
Even if tiger sharks can slow their metabolism, prolonged immobility would still lead to oxygen deprivation as their gill structure is optimized for ram ventilation, not passive respiration.
There is no documented evidence of tiger sharks successfully using buccal pumping for extended periods, reinforcing the reliance on ram ventilation.
Metabolic slowdown in tiger sharks has only been observed in very specific conditions, such as cold environments, and cannot be generalized to all scenarios of immobility.

supporting.text: Some shark species can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over their gills while stationary), and if tiger sharks share this adaptation, stopping swimming may not be fatal.

attacks.text: Some shark species can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over their gills while stationary), and if tiger sharks share this adaptation, stopping swimming may not be fatal.
Tiger sharks are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they rely on continuous swimming to pass water over their gills and cannot switch to buccal pumping.
Even if tiger sharks could buccal pump, the energy cost of staying stationary in open water would make long-term survival unlikely.
Some obligate ram ventilators have been observed exhibiting occasional stationary behavior in areas with strong currents, suggesting possible flexibility.
Energy costs of buccal pumping may be offset by reduced movement energy expenditure when stationary.
Observed stationary behavior in ram ventilators typically lasts only minutes and occurs in very specific current conditions, not supporting long-term viability.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks are highly active predators; stopping swimming would impair their ability to hunt, leading to starvation even if oxygen intake isn't immediately compromised.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks are highly active predators; stopping swimming would impair their ability to hunt, leading to starvation even if oxygen intake isn't immediately compromised.
Tiger sharks can rely on scavenging for food when unable to hunt actively, reducing the risk of starvation.
Some shark species exhibit periods of reduced activity without starvation; tiger sharks may have similar adaptations.
Scavenging opportunities are unreliable and insufficient to meet the high metabolic demands of tiger sharks.
Tiger sharks lack the physiological adaptations seen in less active shark species for prolonged inactivity.
Tiger sharks have been observed successfully scavenging in diverse environments, suggesting reliable food sources.
Metabolic studies show tiger sharks can lower energy expenditure during periods of inactivity.

supporting.text: In rare cases, tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in areas with strong currents, suggesting they may survive brief pauses in swimming under specific conditions.

attacks.text: In rare cases, tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor in areas with strong currents, suggesting they may survive brief pauses in swimming under specific conditions.
Most tiger sharks do not have access to areas with strong enough currents to facilitate resting without swimming, making this behavior irrelevant to the general population.
Even in strong currents, resting tiger sharks may still experience reduced oxygen intake, which could lead to stress or long-term health issues.
Studies on other shark species show that some can actively pump water over their gills while stationary, suggesting tiger sharks might have similar adaptations.
The presence of tiger sharks in diverse habitats indicates they may seek out areas with suitable currents when needing to rest, making the behavior more common than implied.
No direct evidence exists that tiger sharks possess the buccal pumping mechanism observed in some other shark species.
Even if tiger sharks seek strong currents, such areas are limited in availability and may expose them to higher predation risk or competition.

supporting.text: The claim assumes 'nothing in particular happens,' but even temporary cessation of swimming would disrupt their sensory and navigational systems, which rely on water flow.

attacks.text: The claim assumes 'nothing in particular happens,' but even temporary cessation of swimming would disrupt their sensory and navigational systems, which rely on water flow.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor, suggesting they can survive without continuous swimming.
Some shark species have evolved buccal pumping to force water over their gills while stationary, which tiger sharks might also utilize.
Resting behavior in tiger sharks is rare and not well-documented, making it an unreliable counterpoint to their typical obligate ram ventilation.
Buccal pumping is energetically costly and inefficient for large sharks like tiger sharks, limiting its viability as an alternative to swimming.
Even rare observations prove that tiger sharks can survive without swimming, challenging the assumption that it is strictly necessary.
Evolutionary adaptations like buccal pumping may be more efficient than currently understood, especially in low-activity scenarios.
